eventName: In memory of Terry Mears and a Thank You to the Macmillan Nurses.
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Terry Mears
story:
Some of you may know that my amazing,hard working and inspirational grandad, Terry Mears, past away in October 2020. after being diagnosed a year prior, that He had a rare form of cancer called Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). 

MDS is a severe, chronic syndrome from which very few people successfully recover. It often progresses to AML, which is a form of leukaemia. There is no cure for MDS. An allogeneic bone marrow transplant (BMT) is the only potential cure or attempt, to slow it down for patients with MDS. 

My Gramp had his own business which he loved working every day, he loved seeing everyone’s faces and having a chat and a giggle. As well as Coming home to my Nan, and winding her up constantly! His personality and voice is what he’s most known and loved for by many. People would say they could hear him before they see him😄 he loved his cars , especially his new Range..and our crazy family so much. He had the biggest heart and the best stories. He would always tell me how proud of me he was, even if he would then follow off the statement with a sarcastic comment to wind me up. We had the best banter, constantly making fun of each other until one of us would give up! There are many of us, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Who each he had a special bond with, taught life lessons and made us laugh❤️

 However, The cancer slowly but surely ripped all of that away from him. Over the course of a year, he would visit the hospital multiple times a week for scheduled blood transfusions to help him stay as strong as he possibly could. He stayed in hospital multiple times as the year went on. The majority of 2020, he spent in the hospital, which as you can imagine was horrible due to covid we couldn’t visit him anymore. 

He lost his mobility and independence. This was the hardest thing for him to accept, as his mobility and independence was what enabled him to work, drive, socialise and just be him. He had to gain the strength to pretty much learn how to walk again as he had been so unwell for so long, he was too weak to walk and always in pain. This was when it really started to hit home that we’re loosing him.

The final time he went into hospital was the worst. ‘End of life’ care had begun. We put all things in place for him to be able to come home for the remainder of the time we had with him. District nurses and Macmillan cancer nurses would visit multiple times a day to do their checks and care for him. I stayed at the house and worked from home during the day, then would stay awake all night to make sure he wasn’t in any pain or discomfort. Then to call out the nurses if he needed more pain relief etc. As the days went by he deteriorated extremely fast.

He was home for a week fighting his absolute best to stay with us. He finally let himself go to rest on October 10,2020. Hardest and most physically/ emotionally draining week of my life. But him knowing i was by his side, day and night, his last breath is what helps me get through everything. 

I want to raise awareness of this rare cancer, Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). and thank Macmillan nurses for everything they done for my Gramp and our family. I would love to raise some money as a Thank you and work towards a better future with NO CANCER💪

 Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate. Thankyou to anyone who donates and helps the Macmillan charity to continue their amazing care and support.❤️

story:
Well,,, what a year 2020 truly was and to cap things off we were given the devastating news that my beautiful mum has been diagnosed with Stage 4 Ovarian Cancer. Not exactly what we were expecting for Christmas but these are the cards that we’ve been dealt and the only way to tackle them is head on with positivity, love and a touch of humour.

As always my Mum has not wasted any time with self pity or negativity and has got straight into her treatment plan, and this week (w/c 11th Jan 2021) has undergone the first phase of extensive surgery to tackle the cancer. After a short recovery period she will then begin a 4 month chemotherapy treatment plan to hopefully rid her of any remaining cancerous cells and start the road to recovery. But as with all chemotherapy treatments there are serious side effects, one of which includes hair loss.

So, it is with this in mind that we want to show our love and support for our beautiful mum by shaving off our luxurious locks (some more luxurious that others) to raise much needed money for MacMillan Cancer Support, who do amazing work supporting cancer patients along with their family and friends.

For each £200 raised me, my brother and 3 close friends will shave off our hair when the targets are met. Personally, as someone who has been losing his hair since his late 20’s the thought of shaving my hair off makes my "V05 Matt paste" tremble with fear. But, this pales into insignificance when you compare to the challenge my mum is facing with her cancer treatment. This is the very least we can do to show her that she’ll not be alone during this battle and that her family and friends are here with her every step of the way.

We really do appreciate that these are unprecedented times we are living in and any donation, however small, is greatly appreciated.

So, in the words of Sue and Mel...
“On Your Marks,,, Get Set,,, Donate...!!!”

P.S. And don’t worry, post shave photo’s will be updated on this page for your viewing pleasure.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

This JustGiving page has been set up to raise money for the British Heart Foundation in lieu of flowers at my Dad’s funeral on the 28th January 2021.

Dad had his first “silent” heart attack on Christmas Eve in 2012; luckily his GP spotted the signs immediately and we took him to hospital where he was diagnosed and subsequently had stents fitted. His symptoms were not those of a typical heart attack; there were no chest pains, no shortness of breath. He simply felt under the weather and kept having indigestion symptoms.

February 2015 was a day to remember for all the wrong reasons. Dad set off for a bike ride with his Brother John in the morning; without warning he suffered an out of hospital cardiac arrest less than a minute from home. His heart went into VF arrest; his Brother and a passer by performed CPR whilst an ambulance responder and ambulance were just minutes away who continued to work in his heart and they eventually stabilised him at Barnsley hospital before being transported to Sheffield’s Northern General Hospital. Here he was placed in an induced coma and had hypothermic therapy, to aid recovery of his brain. My Dad absolutely blew away all of the health care professionals with his strength and determination which saw him make a full recovery despite a 3% chance of survival. What a hero!!! 

I remember a physiotherapist saying that she wished she could bottle my Dad’s determination, as it was incredible. He was our absolute hero.

Dad returned to work, carried on cycling and enjoyed many more hobbies moving forward from his cardiac arrest. He also created many beautiful memories with me, my Mum Julie, and Elliott his Son-in-law; he enjoyed his trips away, especially to Italy and to Malham in the Yorkshire Dales.

Dad also gave me away when I got married in Mexico in March 2018; an experience which I was very privileged to have.

Dad loved cycling; it brought him a great sense of achievement and happiness over the years, as well as keeping him fit and healthy. He was cycling until the very end.

On 3rd January 2021 whilst “Zwifting” with me on a virtual ride, Dad suddenly collapsed and died at home. Despite the best efforts of the paramedics and air ambulance, this time Dad couldn’t be brought back. He died doing his most favourite activity at home. 

My Mum and I are still coming to terms with Dad not being here anymore. It has been a complete shock for us and we can’t imagine life without him. 

We want to donate to the British Heart Foundation to help prevent others from experiencing the same heartbreak that we have experienced as a family.

Thank you for reading.

story:
Lockdown Mileage Initiative in memory of Robb Bridges


Since the beginning of the first lockdown back in March 2020, I decided to record the miles I’ve accrued on my bike rides. I hit 1000 miles in September, but since being back at work and shorter days, it's been challenging to find the time to get out!


In December, I asked some of the other members of the Motor Vehicle team to join me in reaching 2000 miles by 16th March 2021 - a year since I started. So, with 300 miles to achieve, we have been actively recording our miles, either cycling or walking.  This has been valuable in inspiring and motivating one another to get out - even if the weather is not that inviting...


A week before Christmas, we were all shocked by the passing of our friend and colleague Robb Bridges, it now seems only fitting that our mileage initiative should have a positive focus, in memory of Robb and to raise some money for the British Heart Foundation.


Robb was a Motor Vehicle lecturer at Shoreham campus for …. Years who taught many students who now actively work within the industry. Robb was very well respected by colleagues and students, he had a great sense of humour and had invaluable knowledge which he was always willing to share.


Join Us!


It would be great if you want to join us by setting your own mileage target by the 16th March and donating to the BHF as a congratulation to yourself. If you can’t cycle or walk or simply do not want to, how about encouraging someone who is and sponsor them to reach their target?

A ‘Just Giving’ page will be set up in recognition of our efforts and targets so we can raise money for the British Heart Foundation in memory of Robb which we hope will bring some comfort to his family when we publish the total achieved with them in March.


Garry Budgen, Motor Vehicle PL

In July 2017 my wife’s uncle suffered a massive heart attack with no known risk factors. He was placed on the emergency heart transplant list and in jan 2018 had a successful heart transplant.

In may 2020 during the Covid-19 pandemic having only turned 50 years old he passed away suddenly. 

It just goes to show that heart problems really can happen to anyone and others have not been as lucky to even have a successful heart transplant. Suitable hearts do not become available for everyone and around one in six people do not receive the heart transplant they require.

Please make your intentions regarding organ donation clear to your family. You could help save so many lives: 

It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures.  So I’m braving the shave after a year of growing my beard, much to my entire families enjoyment. Please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

Something in the Chemotherapy caused his heart to slowly stop working. Dad loved anything sweet especially chocolate and so do I. So I’d like to take part in this challenge in memory of my dad. ❤️ Please help me to raise some money towards this amazing charity so that others may benefit from the charities work. 

  The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Barbara Wallace
story:
My lovely mum, Barbara, had a heart attack on her 59th birthday from which she never recovered and sadly passed away 18 days later.

Whilst in intensive care, her amazing medical team gave me some very wise words of advise about my own health and future which inspired me to make complete lifestyle changes to lose weight, give up smoking and to make myself the fittest and healthiest version of myself I could be.  

Inspired by a member of my Slimming World Group, I'm taking on this challenge to go 31 days without chocolate or sweets as although I'm now 8 stone lighter, chocolate and sweets are still one of my biggest temptations and I'm going to need all of my willpower and motivation to complete this challenge.

Charities have been hit so hard during 2020 and now 2021 and every penny I can raise during my challenge will help the British Heart Foundation continue their research to helping people like my mum live a longer and healthier life.

story:
Thank you for your support again with my month-long DECHOX!

This March I'm challenging myself to yet another Dechox! This is the 6th year I will be taking part and I know I'm going to find it tough! (I always do!)

I’m chucking the chocolate to help the British Heart Foundation fund its life-saving heart research. That means absolutely no chocolate bars, no chocolate cake, no choccy biscuits with my tea, not even any chocolate sprinkles on my cappuccino are allowed. And that’s why I need your help.

I have many reasons for supporting this charity including there being a history of heart attacks and strokes in my family, a dear friends husband dying suddenly of a heart attack and also my lovely mum having a heart valve replacement in 2012 due to being born with a bicuspid aortic valve. 

I too was born with a bicuspid aortic valve, and during my annual checkup in 2016 it was found that it has impacted my aorta causing it to dilate. This means that I will need both the valve and the aorta replaced at some point in the future. 

The British Heart Foundation does so much worthwhile research and I'm very grateful ❤

I hope you will be able to spare a £1 or 2 to support me.

Thank you ❤

My page donations will be sent direct to the British Heart Foundation in a fast and secure way. Your support will help beat heartbreak from the world's biggest killers. Conditions like heart diseases, stroke and vascular dementia. Your support funds research that helps to keep families together.

Note from The BFH:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60-year history and it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more.

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funneled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
In 1852, Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) opened with just 10 beds, and was the first hospital in the UK to offer dedicated inpatient care to children.

From world firsts in surgery and state-of-the-art buildings to pioneering research and celebrity support, see some of our highlights and the people who have made them happen - history | Great Ormond Street Hospital (gosh.nhs.uk)

GOSH is a dedicated children’s hospital who specialise in finding and developing the best ways to deal with childhood illnesses. 

GOSH’s mission is to ‘help the sickest children with complex health needs to fulfil their potential’, there key mission statement is to put the ‘child first and always’.

I'm going to be 50 on Friday 22nd January 2021 and I would really love it, if you would help me celebrate by donating to my JustGiving page for Cancer Research UK. story:
Mersey Marauders FC are asking for donations to Marie Curie hospice in memory of Mersey Marauder player, committee member and friend to all of us, Gavin Whitfield, who passed away following a battle with cancer.

Gav joined the Mersey Marauders in 2018, and immediately threw himself into Marauders life. Gavin became Commercial Officer on our Committee, and was instrumental in organising the GFSN national football tournament here in Liverpool in summer 2019. He single-handedly managed to bag Liverpool's Town Hall for the evening social event – nothing smaller would do, and it was a fantastic night!

Gav was passionate at promoting and driving our Club forward. He did not shy away from the limelight – and made appearances in the Liverpool Echo, BBC Radio Merseyside and even on Granada Reports! Gavin was a fierce competitor on the pitch too. He was not shy of a tackle and a word with the opposition, ref or even his own team! The no 25 shirt will always be Gavin's.

Gav loved socialising, and always travelled around the UK with the Club to play in away matches. In Summer 2019 he travelled with a group of Marauders to Rome to play in a European tournament, which he loved every minute of. Gavin was funny, caring and intelligent, he had many close friends on the team. He will be dearly missed by us all.

Marie Curie Hospice in Liverpool gave Gavin outstanding care in the latter stages of his life. We are asking for donations to Marie Curie in his memory. 

Here is some more information about the vital work they do:

'At the Marie Curie Hospice, Liverpool, we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones every day of the year. Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by local people who freely volunteer their time and energy to help us run the hospice. As well as being a place where people can stay to get the expert care they need in a friendly and homely setting, we also support people visiting with clinics and therapies. These include yoga, exercise classes and relaxation. People using the day unit can also get together over a freshly cooked lunch from our chefs. Relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish to. We need to raise £6,397 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in in Liverpool, get the care and support they need.'

Our thoughts are with all of Gavin's family and friends, and his partner Adam during this time.

Thank you for visiting our JustGiving page.
Since the pandemic began in early 2020 we have had to cancel a large number of events and have been unable to be out and about talking to you about the work of the RNLI in and around Harrogate
This is having a huge effect on donations which is why we are coming out to our friends, families and supporters virtually to ask for your help - we rely on donations from you the general public and without your support we wouldn't be able to continue saving lives at sea.
The covid-19 pandemic has brought a new risk to our volunteers that we never could have predicted or imagined but our brave and courageous crew members continue to risk their lives to save others.
We hope that you can support us by donating on our page - we look forward to seeing you soon, stay safe.

story:
On Sunday 27th June I am walking the second half of the Ultra Cotswold Way challenge for the Worldwide Wildlife Fund. At present I am doing this on my own and will be walking 47k (29.20 miles)  from Wotton Under Edge to Cirencester. 

I know this is going to be hard going as in 2016 I walked 26.5 miles for Macmillan along the Cotswold Way from Hillesly to Bath. My motivation for this was inspired by watching 'Wild' with Reece Witherspoon a true story about a young woman who walked the PCT in America after loosing her mother to try and  find herself again. Sadly, in 2018 I suddenly lost my own Mother and the same reason has challenged myself inside to do this walk. 

I am raising money for the WWF as nature and conservation is something very close to my heart as many of you know. There are not many opportunities to raise money for animal charities through events like this, especially locally and so I have in a moment of madness, grabbed this opportunity with both hands. 

If you could help me on my way to rasing my minimum amount of £395 for a great charity however big or small your donation, I would be ever so grateful. 

Wish me luck 🍀🙈😂🥾🥾🐼🦒🐘

story:
Hi Everyone,

Here's a story to positively set the mood for 2021 of how a Health & Safety consultancy specialising in HSE services for the Wind Power and the Renewable Energy market have formed a relationship with a talented Team GB athlete. 3Spires Safety and Frazer Clarke formed a partnership back in early 2018 with 3Spires supporting Frazer in his bid to win a Commonwealth gold medal in Australia. In 2019 Frazer & 3Spires goal was achieved with Frazer scooping gold in the super heavyweight boxing
category.

2 years on and Frazer is now diligently preparing for one of the most globally recognised & prestigious sporting competitions of all time, the Olympic Games. Having endured the set back of COVID 19 postponing the original 2020 date for the Tokyo Olympic games, Frazer now has his eyes and mind firmly set on the rescheduled date and opening ceremony of July 24th 2021.

It became clear through this successful partnership that Joshua Payne (3Spires MD) and Frazer Clarke both shared further common goals and passionate personal interests in the
Environment and how best to tackle the impending threat of climate change. To which extent Frazer & 3Spires Safety are now promoting the Cool Earth charity foundation and decisively we have a keen interest in Queens canopy project UK. Cool Earth - https://www.coolearth.org/

We find our story and our common goals unique and we plan to promote, educate and encourage local community involvement in our Environmental initiatives. We encourage you all to donate in our “fight outside the ring”! Let's all fight climate change together.

3Spires M.D Joshua Payne said “ Being already a part of the Wind Power boom across Europe is something I’m very proud of, but it shouldn't just rest there when there are countries and communities that need educating as to why we need to collectively move in this direction together. From a personal aspect, my first daughter is due April 2021 and I'm incredibly passionate about ensuring her children have sustainable futures through the lessons we currently set in the present. What extraordinary story 3Spires & Frazer have, and the perfect platform to promote environmental change through the Olympics and
beyond. “

Frazer Clarke said “When 3Spires approached me on how we can
partner to promote such a key message there was no hesitation. The irony was that I’ve been self-educating for some time on how to personally decrease my family’s environmental footprint having been inspired by some of David Attenborough’s incredible documentaries. I have a baby boy due in June 2021 & along with his big sister Mila, and my future grandchildren I feel that I have a fantastic platform in the Olympic Games and my professional career ahead of me to transmit a message that resonates with my local community and fans internationally. I’m more focused than ever to fight for the causes that I believe in! “

Contributing to our donation page is one of the best ways you can push for climate change action and take on the biggest issue of our generation. It does not matter how little you contribute but please help us and our partners in the quest to reverse Co2 emissions by
2030!

The clock is ticking and we need your help people!! 

Share our story and please donate to our cause!
